titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: The Archaeological Society of Delaware was founded in 1933 as a professional association for local archaeologists. Over its history, the Society has excavated historic and prehistoric sites, lobbied for Delaware legislation to protect local sites and to hire a State Archaeologist, and raised awareness of the science among the population of the state. The Society publishes the Bulletin of the Archaeological Society of Delaware, Inksherds (the Society's newsletter), and various monographs and papers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of the Archeological Society of Delaware. Materials include: correspondence; minutes of general meetings and of the Board of Directors; membership records and directories; financial records, copies of the Bulletin of the Archeological Society of Delaware and Inksherds (1933-1996); and annual reports of the Eastern States Archaeological Federation which contain annual reports of the Society. The collection includes the correspondence of Dr. Leon De Valinger, Archibald Crozier, and Herbert Pratt, who served as secretaries of the society, as well as newspaper publicity about the society and its members compiled mostly by Arthur G. Volkman.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Provenance: Gift of or purchase from Archaeological Society of Delaware

otherfindaid.p: A paper finding aid is available in the repository.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: University of Delaware: Eastern States Archaeological Federation collection.
